fields.headline: Radio review: Don't Start
fields.bodyText: Don't Start (Radio 4), Frank Skinner's new comedy, focuses on the rows between a long-term couple, Neil (Skinner) and Kim (Katherine Parkinson). Each episode is a short immersion into an argument triggered by something trivial. Last night's began with Kim asking Neil who a text message was from. Within moments, they were bickering: at first about whether they were in fact arguing. "I'm niggled," Kim said. "I would say I was post-niggled," Neil told her. From here it lurched, with horrible accuracy, into a full-scale, fast-escalating falling out. What distinguishes the writing here – and makes it regularly hilarious – is how Skinner captures the cliches and patterns of rows, their terrible predictability, but also their fuming weirdness. His couple are well-read, and so many of the insults are of a literary bent. "Kim, you can go as DH Lawrence as you like," Neil snapped. "You laughed in a Beckettian way because you see our relationship as a barren wasteland," she retorted. At various points, they both sang like a Greek chorus commenting on the spat. The programme also relishes the oddness of how relationships proceed over time. They end up considering a household ban on both the friend who sent the text message and celery, based on an earlier two-pronged resolution to another bitter tussle, "the pornography and doughnut pact".
